etymologies: mid 16th century (in an earlier sense). From post-classical Latin emphaticus emphatic + -al

notes.text: In modern use emphatic is the usual word; emphatical was more common until the 18th century

definitions: Especially of language: powerfully and forcibly expressive; spoken with force or emphasis.
Of an action, attribute, argument, etc.: strongly marked; powerful, forceful.
Of a word, syllable, etc.: that bears the stress in pronunciation. Also of a word: that has particular importance in a sentence.
Designating colours that are not inherent in an object, such as those produced by a prism or seen in a rainbow, regarded as being less real than colours seen on the surface of something.
